chapter.fullItemName: When to suspect an ectopic pregnancy
chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect an ectopic pregnancy?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Ectopic pregnancy can present with a wide variety of symptoms and signs which may be atypical and can resemble those of other more common conditions (such as urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal conditions).

  • Suspect ectopic pregnancy in a woman who presents with any of the following:
    • Common symptoms:
      • Abdominal or pelvic pain.
      • Amenorrhoea or missed period.
      • Vaginal bleeding (with or without clots).
    • Less common symptoms:
      • Breast tenderness.
      • Gastrointestinal symptoms (such as diarrhoea and/or vomiting). 
      • Dizziness, fainting, or syncope.
      • Shoulder tip pain.
      • Urinary symptoms.
      • Passage of tissue.
      • Rectal pressure or pain on defecation.
  • Be aware that:
    • Symptoms generally appear 6–8 weeks after the last normal menstrual period (or much later for a non-tubal ectopic pregnancy).
    • Risk factors (such as previous ectopic pregnancy or previous pelvic inflammatory disease) may be present; however, in about a third of cases, there are no identifiable risk factors.
  • If any of these symptoms are present:
    • Confirm pregnancy with a urine pregnancy test (if not already done).
    • Examine the woman for signs of an ectopic pregnancy. See the section on Managing suspected ectopic pregnancy for information on how to examine the woman.
      • Common signs of an ectopic pregnancy include abdominal tenderness, pelvic tenderness, and adnexal tenderness.
      • Less common signs include cervical motion tenderness, rebound tenderness or peritoneal signs, pallor, abdominal distension, enlarged uterus, tachycardia (more than 100 beats per minute) or hypotension (less than 100/ 60 mmHg), shock or collapse, and orthostatic hypotension.
  • Be alert for symptoms and signs of tubal rupture and intra-abdominal bleeding. For example:
    • Vomiting and diarrhoea may be the presenting symptoms of abdominal bleeding. 
    • Shoulder pain may be caused by irritation of the diaphragm due to leakage of blood from the implantation site.
    • Pallor, tachycardia, hypotension, and shock or collapse may indicate tubal rupture and severe bleeding.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: When to suspect an ectopic pregnancy
Scenario: Follow up after an ectopic pregnancy

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage: Diagnosis and initial management [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012; NICE, 2012].

Symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy

  • The symptoms suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy are based on moderate- and low-quality evidence from 29 studies (24 retrospective case series, four prospective observational studies, and one case control study) reviewed by the NICE guideline development group (GDG) [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012]. 
    • Most women presented with:
      • Abdominal or pelvic pain (93%, 21 studies).
      • Amenorrhoea (73%, 11 studies).
      • Vaginal bleeding (64%, 25 studies).
    • Less common symptoms included:
      • In 20–30% of women — breast tenderness (three low-quality studies), gastro-intestinal symptoms (10 studies), dizziness, fainting, or syncope (12 studies).
      • In 10–20% of women — shoulder tip pain (seven studies) and urinary symptoms (three low-quality studies).
      • In less than 10% of women — passage of tissue (two studies) and rectal pressure or pain on defecation (three low-quality studies).
  • The information on when symptoms generally appear is based on a British Medical Journal (BMJ) Best Practice review article on ectopic pregnancy [BMJ, 2017].

Risk factors

  • The NICE GDG recognized that risk factors were not a helpful method for identifying women with an ectopic pregnancy, as about a third of women with an ectopic pregnancy have no identifiable risk factors [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012]. 
  • The GDG agreed that risk factors should not be used as a diagnostic aid and that even if there are no identifiable risk factors, the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy should always be ruled out [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012]. 

Confirming pregnancy with a pregnancy test

  • The NICE GDG recognized that women who have an ectopic pregnancy may present with a wide variety of non-specific symptoms and signs and therefore recommends that healthcare professionals should always consider the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy in women of reproductive age, and think about offering a pregnancy test even when symptoms are non-specific [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012].

Signs of an ectopic pregnancy

  • The signs suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy are based on moderate- and low-quality evidence from 29 studies (24 retrospective case series, four prospective observational studies, and one case control study) reviewed by the NICE GDG [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2012]. 
    • Most women with an ectopic pregnancy had at least one of the following:
      • Pelvic tenderness (91%, one study).
      • Adnexal tenderness (82%, seven studies).
      • Abdominal tenderness (78%, 11 studies).
    • Other important but less common signs included:
      • In 40–75% of women — cervical motion tenderness (eight studies) and rebound tenderness or peritoneal signs (nine studies).
      • In 20–40% of women — abdominal distension (two low-quality studies), an enlarged uterus (six studies), an adnexal mass (nine studies), and tachycardia or hypotension (five low-quality studies).
      • In less than 20% of women — a palpable pelvic mass (two studies), collapse or shock (eight studies), or orthostatic hypotension (three studies).
    • Although reported in the evidence, the NICE GDG felt that it was not appropriate to include ‘adnexal mass’ or ‘palpable pelvic mass’ in the list of symptoms and signs. From their clinical experience, they noted that palpation can increase the risk of an ectopic pregnancy rupturing. They also felt that palpation to detect an internal mass is no longer appropriate due to the development of new diagnostic modalities (such as transvaginal ultrasound and biochemical tests).

Being alert for the clinical features of tubal rupture and intra-abdominal bleeding

  • The Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (CMACE) recommends that ectopic pregnancy should be ruled out in women who present with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and vomiting. According to The Eighth Report of the Confidential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths in the United Kingdom published by the CMACE, four of the six women who died from early ectopic pregnancies in the 3-year period 2006–2008 were misdiagnosed initially with gastrointestinal problems [CMACE, 2011].
  • The other clinical features of rupture and intra-abdominal bleeding are based on expert opinion in review articles on ectopic pregnancy [Jurkovic, 2011; Crochet, 2013; BMJ, 2017].
